instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
No backlight

Some readings 

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP>
Pin 1&2 <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL> = 0.1v
Pin 4 <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FET_DRV</SIGNAL> = 0v
Pin 5 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL> = 5.15v
Pin 18 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> = 5.15v
Pin 17 <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.34v

Thank you

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
12.38v <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>
12.56v both sides of f7700 
Fuse has continuity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
"12.38v <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL>
---------
If good"
Is NOT!

Did you try another compatible LCD assembly?
Check <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>-53 and traces.
Post voltage and diode mode on SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
What should <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> be to be good? LCD Assembly good tried on working MacBook.

<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 4.62v  0.468
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 4.54v 0.464
<RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR> to 53 all good. Traces appear fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
Backlight adjust is controlled through I2C bus, via PCH -> T-CON -> <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> must be 0V, in working state; controlled as mentioned.

Try chabging U700.
Check all its connections.
Be sure no short anywhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
If you mean <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> then I have changed it but the same problem persists. Thanks

I will check to see if there are any shorts to its connectors

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message: When I'm checking voltages at <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> should I have the screen plugged in or does it not make a difference?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
Yeah, <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
I supposed all previous readings are with LCD connected.
If not, wasted time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
Yes all readings were carried out WITHOUT screen connected.
Shall I do them again with screen connected and send them too you?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message:
Of course.
How do you expect to get backlight voltage, if no LCD connected.
I already explained you the via for required communication; T-CON is inside LCD assembly!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Backlight
threads.message: There was a short on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SO_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> caused by a bad LVDS connector. Replaced connector and now all good. Thanks again for your help and support. Until the next one - Adios!
